title: Overall equation for destruction of O3

content.description: The particle models shown above represent a proposed two-step mechanism for the destruction of ozone (<math alttext="O 3 " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) in the upper atmosphere.
content.question: Based on the proposed mechanism, what is the balanced chemical equation for the overall reaction?

choices.label: <math alttext="O 3 gas plus C l gas react to produce O 2 gas plus C l O gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>ClO</mtext></mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2 O 3 gas plus 2 C l gas react to produce 2 O 2 gas plus 2 C l O gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"></mspace><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"></mspace><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>2</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"></mspace><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"></mspace><mtext>ClO</mtext></mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="O 3 gas plus C l gas plus C l O gas react to produce 2 O 2 gas plus C l 2 gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>ClO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>2</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.250em"></mspace><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2 O 3 gas reacts to produce 3 O 2 gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="2 O 3 gas reacts to produce 3 O 2 gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
